Design Systems

Design Systems Workshops

Looking to jump start a design system program? We workshop with team(s) to teach methods, conduct actvities, and plan a future to get the most out of a system.

What We Cover

Design systems cover alot of ground. Architecting a high-quality library of design, code and documentation is essential. So to is operating a program, from forming a vision and roadmap to aligning people, processes, and contributions from a wide community.

EightShapes will customize a workshop for you that blends and prioritizes topics across a day or two together. For each topic, we'll find the right balance of lecture, hands-on activities, discussion, and – if you're ready – critique of your team's materials. If a default agenda suits your needs, excellent! Need to focus on some topics more than others? We'll customize an agenda to suit your needs.

The Architecting Design Systems one-day workshop is ideal for teams looking to lift the quality of visual style and UI components across design, code, and documentation.

  • Arrival

    8:30AM

  • Visual Language

    9:00AM - 10:45AM

    • Welcome &amp; Agenda
    • Color
    • Typography
    • Space
    • Size
    • Tokens Activity

  • Design

    11:00AM – 12:30pm

    • Inventories and Scoping Activity
    • Buttons
    • Classification
    • Decomposition &amp; Hierarchy
    • UX Patterns
    • Workflow: Designing a Component Activity

  • Lunch

    12:30pm – 1:30pm

  • Code

    1:30pm – 3:00pm

    • Getting Started with a Design System
    • Techincal Architecture: Tools and Templates
    • Component Quality
    • Component Testing Plans Activity
    • Workflow: Coding a Component Activity

  • Documentation

    3:15PM – 5:00pm

    • Cards &amp; Composibility
    • Documenting Components
    • Component Examples Activity
    • Design Guidelines Activity
    • Code Reference Activity
    • Workflow: Documenting a Component Activity

  • End of Day

    5:00pm

The Operating Design Systems one-day workshop is ideal for teams considering the vision, plan and operations of a design system within their organization. The workshop covers objectives, roadmapping, adoption, processes and workflows, reorienting teams and cultivating design and developer communities of contribution.

  • Arrival

    8:30AM

  • How's It Fit?

    9:00AM - 10:30AM

    • Welcome &amp; Agenda
    • Defining Your System Activity
    • Coordinating Adoption
    • System Hierarchy
    • System Competition and Consolidation
    • Diagramming System Architectures Activity

  • Who's Involved?

    10:45AM – 12:00pm

    • Team Models
    • Core Team Activity
    • Design System Leaders &amp; Managers
    • Design &amp; Development Communities
    • Contributions Activity

  • Lunch

    12:00pm – 1:00pm

  • Make What, by When?

    1:00pm – 3:00pm

    • Starting a System
    • Releases
    • Versions
    • Roadmapping a Release Cycle Activity
    • Visual Breaking Changes Activity

  • Iterate How Often, to Where?

    3:15PM – 5:00pm

    • Iterations, Task Management &amp; Ceremonies
    • Communications
    • Measuring Success
    • Closing Discussion

  • End of Day

    5:00pm

Most in-house teams choose to customize their agenda to tailor topics to their needs. This may result in a workshop lengthened to two days or shortened to a half day.

Example 1: Evening Talk, then Half–Day Workshop

One client paired a sponsored talk for a local meetup with a customized half-day in-house workshop. Their objectives were to align multiple system efforts and better serve system customers and contributors. As a result, they omitted most topics of design, code and documentation.

  • Arrival

    9:30am

  • Planning

    10:00 – 11:45am

    • Defining Design Systems
      What should our system be?
    • Consolidating Systems
      How do we compare and rationalize multiple design systems?
    • Measuring Success Activity
      What are our objectives, and how do we track if we get there?
    • Tokens
      How do we share a visual langauge across products and platforms?

  • Lunch

    11:45pm – 12:30pm

  • Practicing

    12:30pm – 2:00pm

    • Designing a Systems Team
      How can we form a vocabulary for team members, users, and contributors?
    • How Do I...? Processes Activity
      What are the main activities and processes used to operate a systems team?
    • Adopting Design Systems
      Who uses our system, and how do we monitor their work?
    • Contributing
      How do we know what goes in, and what is the process to get it done?

  • End of Day

    2:00pm

Example 2: Customized Full-Day Workshop

Another client was well experienced but needed deep dives. In particular, they had two systemes: one four-year old, another emerging from other groups.

Their workshop customized of existing topics and added new material based on top-level findings. Following planning sessions, stakeholder interviews, and system tours, the workshop's agenda was:

  • Arrival

    8:00am

  • System Definition & Rationalizing Features

    8:30am – 10:00am

  • System Teams, Roles & Community Collaboration

    10:15am – 11:00am

  • Design: Tokens, Space & Size

    11:15am – 12:00pm

  • Lunch

    12:00pm – 1:00pm

  • Documenting Component Examples and Guidelines

    1:00pm – 2:15pm

  • Contributions Across Teams, Groups, and Lines of Business

    2:30pm – 3:45pm

  • Measuring Success and Next Steps

    4:00pm – 5:00pm

  • End of Day

    5:00pm

When customizing a workshop, we’ll select topics and activities that fit your needs. Topics available out-of-the-box include:

  • Typography
  • Space
  • Size
  • Light & Dark Modes
  • Tokens
  • Reference Designs
  • Cropping Line Height

  • Cards and Composability

  • Component QA
  • Component Testing Plans
  • Getting Developers Started

Strategy

  • A Product, Serving Products
  • Defining
  • Principles
  • Adoption
  • Platform Balance
  • Accessibility
  • Measuring Success
  • Reach

Systems of Systems

  • Tiers
  • Intermediaries
  • Consolidation
  • Architecture Diagrams

  • Cadence
  • Versioning
  • Visual Breaking Change

Contributions

Process

People

  • Team Models
  • Designing a Team
  • Leaders and Managers

Workshop Activities

  • Component Cut Up
  • Parts, Products and People
  • How Do I? Cards

Prepping for the Day

Once you're signed up, we’ll meet at least three times to plan the event. For workshops requiring customization or additional consulting, we'll add activities as needed — interviews, more tours, etc — so that we can present material most effectively for your audience.

Meeting 1 (60 min)

Objectives, Topics and Draft Agenda

We'll workshop the workshop, drafting objectives, themes, topics, activities, and what excites each of us.

Meeting 2 (90 min)

Design System and Experience Tours

EightShapes quickly immerses in your system's existing design, code and doc and tours the products it's used for.

Meeting 3 (60 min)

Final Agenda, Materials and Logistics

We'll confirm the day's agenda, any materials and custom content to be produced, and finalize logistics.

Who Should You Invite?

The workshop format is suitable for up to 100 participants and covers content relevant to disciplines beyond just designers and engineers.

Essential Participants

  • Teams making system(s)
  • UX and visual designers
  • Front-end engineers
  • Design and engineering leaders
  • Design ops management

Additional Invites

  • Product managers
  • Accessibility specialists
  • Content strategists
  • Researchers
  • Executive sponsors

Why EightShapes for a Workshop?

EightShapes’ experience and enthusiasm will inspire and challenge your teams. Sessions will engage participants in hands-on activities, spark new ideas and moderate challenging conversations so your team can:

  • Learn about design systems
  • Kickoff or energize a program
  • Define a system and what it offers
  • Dive into topics like color and space
  • Name a team & energize a community
  • Decide how contributions flow in
  • Plan how other teams adopt over time
  • Identify measurable outcomes
Even as an experienced design systems pro, I picked up new techniques and concepts that I never knew about. Listening to Nathan and discussions as a class helped me get some perspective on issues I was facing at work.
Jeff Crossman, Design System Lead, JPMorgan Chase & Co.
